ContentClassification.TableReference: K. Ebihara (1910), reprinted James W. Glover, “United States Life Tables 1890,1901, 1910, and 1901-1910 with Explanatory Text, Mathematical Theory, Computations, Graphs and Original Statistics, also Tables of United States Life Annuities, Life Tables of Foreign Countries, Mortality Tables of Life Insurance Companies”, Department of Commerce, Bureau of the Census (Washington, 1921). Accessed: March, 2014 from http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/lifetables/life1890-1910.pdf
ContentClassification.TableDescription: Three Japanese Offices Table - J^M(5). Minimum Age: 10 Maximum Age: 98
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: Tables produced by Mr. K. Ebihara, the first gentleman of Japanese nationality to obtain Fellowship of the Institute of Actuaries by way of examination. Work published in both English and Japanese in 1912, a notable achievement considering extent of data. Main methods for data collection parallel those of the British Offices Life Tables (see SOA Table Identities 254 and 255). Data came from the three oldest Japanese offices: “Meiji” (established 1888), “Teikoku” (established 1888) and “Nippon” (established 1888). Observation period covered the whole history of these three companies from formation to the end of 1905. Lives in military service and emigrants were excluded to eliminate additional risks of the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905). Data of the investigation used healthy assured lives, male and female, and who were assured under whole life and endowment policies. Although the data is draw from Japanese assured lives, British actuaries may find the distinctive features of the table prove useful in the investigation of extra risks. Methodology: Twelve tables were constructed but only three tables were graduated with J^M and J^M(5) the most important. Presented here is the J^M(5); that is, the table constructed excluding the first 5 years of data to eliminate the effects of selection. A Spencer’s 21-term summation formula was used, supplemented by a graphic process at the early ages and by a Makeham model at older ages. Data Transcription Errors: None. Data Certified: 01/2014

MetaData.TableDescription: Three Japanese Offices Table - J^M(5). Minimum Age: 10 Maximum Age: 98
